body: Yes, this should be solvable with some suitable atrribute

I would go a step further and say using the same character and changing the colour is also a problem for colour blind people.
Maybe we should make the "Out of Sync" symbol ◻ (`◻`) and the "Stopped" symbol ⛔ (`⛔`)
Or something similar.
In terms of the screen reader I think adding `role="status"` to the entire panel and `role="img" aria-label="Out of Sync"` to the icon span might work but I could be way off.

body: Fully agreed. We have limited space but there's no excuse to not provide at least some iconage plus suitable screen reader attributes.

you can simply use [any icon](http://fontawesome.io/icons/) from the already included icon font. The "box" was added (see https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/commit/2aac1cde04b470d1d1b80855b917a0336ba51d4a) before font-awesome was there to show a block on smaller screen resolutions which could be colored differently.

bootstrap.css already has some [screen reader CSS classes](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/01c70caa8f43f904b205b5e9e1957a676fea3ac4/gui/default/vendor/bootstrap/css/bootstrap.css#L282) so maybe adding one of these in should do the trick for this specific bug. As I understand it, they're hidden unless the content is being processed by a screen reader.

issue.body:
I'm adding some minor accessibility fixes (mainly cosmetic) to your web gui (I'm a blind computer user and active member of the [NVDA](http://www.nvaccess.org) project) and use syncthing for maintaining many files on a subdomain of http://derekriemer.com . First off, great job on your User interface. It's really easy to understand and structured well, and because of syncthing, I have a much easier way of adding files to my website than having to jump through my many layers of authentication to connect via sftp. The minor fixes I can include are:
- There should be a heading level one somewhere on the page to comply with HTML best practices.
- Either an alt tag should be added to each of the syncthing logos that are created on line 35 of index.htm, or the span should be marked with aria-hidden="true" to convey to assistive technology to ignore these two logos.
- the language menu incorrectly has aria-expanded="true" rather than aria-expanded="false" when it starts up. Therefore, Syncthing reports "English expanded" rather than "english collapsed" as it should when the drop down is not shown.
- The actions menu does not have aria-expanded="false" on it, which causes it to report as a link, and not a link that can be expanded. This doesn't cause the link you click to activate to have any accessibility issues (The angular dropdown I think is fixing this after an expand/collapse cycle as well). Once the user activates the link, the dropdown is accessible, this is simply a cosmetic fix to alert users of Assistive Technologies that a dropdown menu exists.
- Optionally, we could add roles of menu and menuitem to each of the dropdowns code (on the ul and li tags) to turn the dropdowns into menus that appear when they are activated. If we do this, we should hide the a tags inside the list items from assistive technology.
- role="main" should be added around the area that contains the folders, and devices, to convey to assistive technology that this is the main contents.
- The folders are buttons (as of the last release), but do not have a collapsed state. I could add this by adding aria-expanded="true". I've tried this with the source, and it works great.
- We should add aria-expanded="true" to the button that displays the device name under the heading level 3. This way, assistive technology users know you can collapse this.
- Add collapsed states to each device present in the HTML code under remote devices.
- Some of the tabs on the advanced settings page need cosmetic fixes to the collapsed and expanded states. For example, currently they by default all say expanded, even if they should be collapsed. Note that after you expand and then collapse them, they take on the correct state.
- There are some modal dialogs like the simlinks are disabled that appear and don't ever get focus to set to them. Currently, a user must find them manually.

Thanks.

body: To be clear, I've heard NVDA report "out of sync" before. Is there a different character?

When I zoom it, I hear
"symbol 2 5 f c" 
Since I'm totally blind, I might have to have someone describe the color change necessary.
Thanks.
If someone can find a suitable icon, I could add this.
Also, the same bug can be confirmed on the dropdowns towards the top (Actions, help, and language).
Do you just want to replace the unicode character with an icon? You can use `` which is a simple square icon.

The same thing is reported with a screen reader on the drop down menus if the display is zoomed in. Is this icon visually the same (For example, the language and actions menus)? I'm asking here because I'm totally blind, so if I replace the icons when I add labels, I want to make sure I add the roper icons. Alternatively, I could leave the unicode symbol and hide that span from screen readers, and put aria-label on the whole panel.

They're the same type of icons yes, so that the menu reduces from being icon+word to just the icon at small widths (or high zoom I guess). Would adding a proper alt/title attribute to the icons make them understandable to screen readers?

(As an aside, is there a rule or convention for the screen "width" presented by screen readers? I would expect it to not matter for the purpose of speaking the page, but unfortunately the page does get less readable as elements are removed or simplified at small widths...)
My guess is that on smaller screens (or equally higher zoom levels) the text is hidden also from screen readers. I think an aria-label on the icon with the current status text could help here
We could add an aria-label to this. The issue is that this wouldn't solve the issue for those who are color blind.

Yes, the code around this are:

https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/master/gui/default/index.html#L271

Has a bunch of characters in the "visible-xs" class with no aria labels.
What needs to be done for this to make it into the next release? I am colourblind myself, and it's indeed impossible to tell green from red boxes.

I expect that [this section](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/abb3fb8a3194c3c0f1c22517bfc7b5c65da0f8ff/gui/default/index.html#L312-L324) and the corresponding ones for devices need to be rewritten to be more accessible. That would mean reasonable aria tags for screen readers and maybe symbols in addition to the colors.

Gentlemen @madduck @derekriemer 
I have added the accessibility features in [PR #5381](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/5381)- please test if this is to your visual/audible liking.
